Award.AwardTitle: CSBR: Natural History Collections: Modernization and Digitization of the Angelo State Natural History Collections
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Angelo State Natural History Collections (ASNHC) house 120,000 voucher specimens of plants, mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians of the Concho Valley, other regions of Texas, the U.S. and the world. The primary goal of this project is to improve researcher and educator access to the specimens and tissues housed in the Collections. The data associated with these specimens and digital images of plant specimens will be made available to researchers around the world. Faculty curators and students will complete data entry, including geo-referencing specimens, update software, and make all data available through existing biodiversity portals. Specific web-based learning modules for K-12 and university level students will be created. Holding facilities will be modernized and integrated pest management systems will be updated to protect specimens.

The broader impacts of this project are diverse. The wider science community will have improved access to ASNHC databases, increasing use of the Collections. K-12 science education throughout the region will benefit from new outreach resources (e.g. digital images) for teachers and students. Angelo State University students, including their own Hispanic Serving Institution target group, will benefit from improved specimen-based instructional resources for classroom and laboratory instruction.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Angelo State Natural History Collections (ASNHC) contain almost 93,000 cataloged botanical and vertebrate specimens from the United States and several countries, but the emphasis of each collection is on the flora and fauna of the Concho Valley region of West-Central Texas. This project has increased opportunities for the ASNHC to interact with the scientific community, especially diversity-based botanists and zoologists. The in-house collection database program was updated from Specify 5 to Specify 6 giving us access to many additional features and the size of the database has grown to incorporate newly-acquired collections and a backlog of specimens that had accumulated in each of the collections. The current numbers of specimens that are cataloged in each database are: 57,406 plants, 16,226 mammals, 2,053 birds, and 14,646 reptiles and amphibians.  New specimens continue to be cataloged and added to the database. Before the support of NSF, none of the specimen data were available online. There is now improved access to a large number of the ASNHC specimens (mammals, birds, reptiles and amphibians, and plants) and the associated data. With the support of NSF, the ASNHC has transformed from a collection with no public access to a highly visible collection where scientists and the general public may access our holdings via online data portals such as VertNet, GBIF, and iDigBio.

 

Another outcome of this project is that over 57,000 herbarium sheets were digitized and many are linked to herbarium records that can be retrieved from the online database.  Approximately 25% of these records have geocoordinates based on locality descriptions and have been georeferenced. More of the vertebrate collections (approximately 80%) have been georeferenced. An electronic map showing a specimen location can be retrieved from the online data portals for these georeferenced specimens.

 

We have modernized storage and updated integrated pest management systems.  These improvements to the collection (raising specimen cases, new freezers for tissue storage and decontaminating specimens, and acquisition of new facilities for fluid-preserved specimens) make the specimens safe for long-term storage ensuring their availability for both educational and scientific purposes. An ultracold freezer with an alarm system was installed as the primary freezer for frozen tissue storage with an older freezer standing by to receive the Frozen Tissue Collection (over 19,000 vials) in the event of an emergency. Overall, the improved collection facilities enhance the value of the resources in the ASNHC. 

 

Improving the protection of our collections and the dissemination of electronic data has increased the visibility and usage of our collections. Scientists have made numerous requests for loans of specimens or tissues and others from outside of our institution have borrowed material for education. We know that others are using the ASNHC information because the online databases have been queried by numerous persons.  For example, in the last year our collection experienced 2,502 searches via VertNet resulting in 106,636 mammal, 34,695 reptile and amphibian, and 3,435 bird records downloaded. Physical specimens from the collection also have been made available for education.  For example, over 100 specimens from the collections were on display for 5 months at the San Angelo Museum of Fine Arts.  This exhibit, viewed by over 3,000 members of the public, displayed natural history specimens in the style of a European Wunderkammer.  One special evening, based on the popular movie “Night at the Museum” featured our collection and student interpreters in period costume.  This event reached an additional 1,800 members of the public.
